Marco Baroni wrote:

> Dear all,
>
> I was happily crawling the web, when I've got an out-of-memory error and
> heritrix hanged up.
>
> I tried to restart the crawl through the recovery option, but heritrix
> died again with an error (pasted at the bottom of this mail) complaining
> about the recover log file being corrupted.

The tail on the recover log is an incomplete compression block; The 
crash interrupted the compressed recover log writing.  Because of this, 
gzip is complaining.

But its just the tail that's bad (Usually something <32k if I recall 
correctly).  All the rest of the log should be good.

Try zcating the recover log to a new file and use this new uncompressed 
file to do the recovery (In your order.xml, set 
/crawl-order/recover-path to point at the new file).

(Uncompressing the recover log seems to be also necessary when the 
recover.gz > 2Gigs).

St.Ack

>
> Now, my question is: given that it looks like I have to start the crawl
> again, is there a way to do so that would minimize overlap with the
> previous crawl?

>
> For example, can I use the list of urls in the previous crawl's crawl.log
> file as a list of pages that heritrix should NOT download this time? If
> so, how?
>
> For my purposes, I don't care if the crawl is "complete", i.e., I prefer
> to avoid crawling the same pages twice, even if this means that I will
> also fail to download pages I originally intended to download.
>
> All this, as part of a surt-prefix crawl based on two simple patterns
> (pages from .de and .at top domains).
>
> Any hint greatly appreciated.
>
> Thanks in advance.
>
> Regards,
>
> Marco
>
